official-title.#text: To establish the National Commission on Effective Marginal Tax Rates for Low-Income Families.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Making Work and Marriage Pay Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The take-home pay of low-income families is subject to reductions from many sources, including the Federal income tax, Social Security payroll taxes, and State income taxes. In addition, eligibility for many Federal and State programs for assistance to working families, such as the earned income tax credit, the child tax credit, supplemental nutritional assistance program, housing assistance programs, Federal and State health care programs, child care assistance, and temporary assistance to needy families, is based in part on income levels. The rates at which the benefits from such programs are phased out have the same disposable income reducing effect as escalating marginal tax rates.

The total effective marginal rate of tax for additional income earned by low-income people can exceed 100 percent and can be a disincentive to working more hours, getting a raise, seeking education toward a more lucrative trade, getting married, or engaging in other economic or social activities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has enacted each of these programs without full consideration of the impact it would have on other existing programs. As a result, the structure of the United States system for the support of low-income families is uncoordinated and contains features which work against the goal of encouraging families to work their way toward self-sufficiency.

text.#text: For purposes of this Act:

text.#text: There is established a commission to be known as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall study and make recommendations on policy changes to mitigate the impact of the effective marginal tax rate and of phaseouts in Federal benefits on low-income earners and their families.

text.#text: Not later than 18 months after the first meeting of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: general recommendations for increasing coordination of the delivery of Federal benefits for low-income families in order to reduce effective marginal tax rates and decrease disincentives to work and marriage.

text.#text: The relative usefulness of sudden benefit cutoffs (sometime referred to as
The interaction of Federal benefits and State assistance programs, and the potential benefits of structuring State programs consistent with the design of Federal assistance.
The maximum extent to which funding for Federal benefits can be appropriated annually avoiding the need to create additional entitlement programs.

The extent to which low-income cohabiting couples (including couples with children and couples without children) resist entering a legal marriage in order to maximize Federal benefits and avoid lost income.
A detailed analysis of the following:
Combining all Federal benefits which are not tax benefits into a single flexible voucher, allowing the beneficiary to allocate funds within each of the supported benefit areas.

Combining all Federal benefits which are tax benefits for low-income families into a coordinated credit that minimizes phaseouts, encourages work, is adjusted for family size, and does not penalize marriage.
Establishing a single eligibility standard for all Federal benefits.
